		<title>Disney Research uses RFID tags to create powerless, low-cost interactive controllers</title>

		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://techcrunch.com/?p=1321709</guid>
		<description><img width="680" height="508" src="https://tctechcrunch2011.files.wordpress.com/2016/05/screen-shot-2016-05-12-at-2-20-17-pm.png?w=680" class="attachment-large size-large wp-post-image" alt="RFID Disney Research" />&nbsp;The team at Disney Research is up to its fun old tricks, this time finding some new uses for off-the-shelf RFID tags. Along with researchers from Carnegie Mellon, Disney&#8217;s laboratory wing has discovered a low-latency way to process RFID signals, making it possible to use the tags to turn cheap objects into simple wireless interactive controls that don&#8217;t require battery power.&hellip; <a href="http://techcrunch.com/2016/05/12/disney-rapid/?ncid=rss">Read More</a><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/TechCrunch/Gaming/~4/iRCUWJW8K2o" height="1" width="1" alt=""/></description>

		<description><img width="680" height="400" src="https://tctechcrunch2011.files.wordpress.com/2016/05/watch-out-grandpa.png?w=680" class="attachment-large size-large wp-post-image" alt="Ooh that&#039;s dark..." />&nbsp;Coffin Dodgers is named for the slang expression for the geriatric. It&#8217;s a racing game where instead of motorbikes, cars or skateboards, you are on a race against death on mobility scooters. Yes, it&#8217;s every bit as ridiculous as it sounds. Tasteless? Perhaps, but also a tremendous amount of fun. The game has been on Steam for a while, and is launching on Xbox One later this week and&hellip; <a href="http://techcrunch.com/2016/05/03/coffin-dodgers/?ncid=rss">Read More</a><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/TechCrunch/Gaming/~4/T9Prnwz7O14" height="1" width="1" alt=""/></description>

		<description><img width="680" height="204" src="https://tctechcrunch2011.files.wordpress.com/2016/04/114303_web.jpg?w=680" class="attachment-large size-large wp-post-image" alt="114303_web" />&nbsp;I know we&#8217;re supposed to be all done talking about Flappy Bird, but I think it&#8217;s justified to bring it up when it appears in a research paper about why games like Flappy Bird are so hard &#8212; and so frustrating. Turns out the controls are fundamentally bad. <a href="http://techcrunch.com/2016/04/28/researchers-propose-theory-on-why-touchscreen-controls-in-mobile-games-are-the-worst/?ncid=rss">Read More</a><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/TechCrunch/Gaming/~4/7e-OPneOhJo" height="1" width="1" alt=""/></description>
